articles.title: WWII hero's remains finally coming home after 80-year mystery is solved through military dedication

neutral.headline: Long Lost WWII Soldier Finally Laid to Rest at Arlington National Cemetery
neutral.body:
After nearly eight decades, the long-lost remains of Army Air Forces 1st Lt. Henry J. Carlin, who went missing in a crash over Burma during World War II back in 1943, have finally been identified. The diligent efforts of forensic experts and researchers have led to the positive identification of Lt. Carlin's remains, bringing closure to his family and honoring his sacrifice.
Lt. Carlin's burial at Arlington National Cemetery serves as a poignant reminder of the many brave men and women who have served and sacrificed for our country. It is a testament to the unwavering commitment to never forget those who have fought for our freedoms and the sacrifices they have made.
The discovery and identification of Lt. Carlin's remains also highlight the ongoing efforts to bring closure to the families of missing service members from past conflicts. It is a poignant reminder of the toll that war takes on individuals and families, and the importance of honoring and remembering those who have made the ultimate sacrifice for their country.
As Lt. Carlin is laid to rest with full military honors, his memory will live on, and his service and sacrifice will be forever remembered and honored by a grateful nation.
